channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Vaccines reduce the risk of long COVID in children
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04032-z

A study shows that US children who received mRNA COVID-19 vaccines have some protection against developing long-lasting symptoms of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2.
item.dc:title: Vaccines reduce the risk of long COVID in children
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall

item.title: Scientists question cancer tests that use microscopic nematode worms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03733-9

Some doctors say a troublingly high number of cancer-free people have tested positive on the tests sold by a Japanese start-up.
item.dc:title: Scientists question cancer tests that use microscopic nematode worms
item.dc:creator: David McNeill
Momoko Suda

item.title: To build a better world, stop chasing economic growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04029-8

The year 2024 must be a turning point for shifting policies away from gross domestic product and towards sustainable well-being. Here’s why and how.
item.dc:title: To build a better world, stop chasing economic growth
item.dc:creator: Robert Costanza

item.content:encoded:

item.dc:title: From the archive: scientific spelling, and ancient Egyptian art

item.dc:creator: Bernardo Gonçalves

item.title: Humans might have driven 1,500 bird species to extinction — twice previous estimates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04065-4

Humans are probably responsible for the extinction of 12% of bird species, many of which were never documented.
item.dc:title: Humans might have driven 1,500 bird species to extinction — twice previous estimates
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Viruses wrap up bacterial defence systems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03796-8

Bacteria use diverse defences against viral predators called bacteriophages. A method to identify antibacterial counter-defences in viral genomes has revealed striking modes of defence inhibition.
item.dc:title: Viruses wrap up bacterial defence systems
item.dc:creator: Tim R. Blower
Stineke van Houte

item.title: Black holes, love and poetry — an artistic exploration of intimacy and adventure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04023-0

A book by physicist Kip Thorne and artist Lia Halloran explores the mysteries of space through poetry and paintings.
item.dc:title: Black holes, love and poetry — an artistic exploration of intimacy and adventure
item.dc:creator: Ron Cowen

item.title: Has your research influenced policy? Use this free tool to check
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04070-7

Sage Policy Profiles scans a database of 10 million documents to show researchers where their papers have been cited.
item.dc:title: Has your research influenced policy? Use this free tool to check
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: The postdoc experience is broken. Funders such as the NIH must help to reimagine it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04028-9

Postdoctoral woes, especially in biomedical research, are symptomatic of a wider problem. Funding bodies have an opportunity to spearhead a cultural shift.
item.dc:title: The postdoc experience is broken. Funders such as the NIH must help to reimagine it
item.dc:creator: Ubadah Sabbagh

item.title: From Einstein to AI: how 100 years have shaped science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04021-2

Looking back a century reveals how much the research landscape has changed — and how unclear the consequences of scientific innovation can be.
item.dc:title: From Einstein to AI: how 100 years have shaped science

item.title: How Dark Souls and Darth Revan helped me to make sense of my professorship
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04080-5

John Tregoning compares academia to role-playing video games as a way to discuss how the choices we make can affect the paths we take.
item.dc:title: How Dark Souls and Darth Revan helped me to make sense of my professorship
item.dc:creator: John Tregoning

item.title: These scientists aren’t using ChatGPT — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04071-6

Some researchers find AI chatbots helpful for writing, coding and gathering information. Others are choosing to avoid the craze.
item.dc:title: These scientists aren’t using ChatGPT — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Does quantum theory imply the entire Universe is preordained?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04024-z

The popular idea that quantum physics implies everything is random and nothing is certain might be as far from the truth as it could possibly be.
item.dc:title: Does quantum theory imply the entire Universe is preordained?
item.dc:creator: Eddy Keming Chen

item.title: Inhaled COVID vaccines stop infection in its tracks in monkey trials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04003-4

New results hint at how to perfect ‘mucosal’ vaccines, which are delivered up the nose or down the throat.
item.dc:title: Inhaled COVID vaccines stop infection in its tracks in monkey trials
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Research prizes are opaque and rife with bias — it’s time to shake them up
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04027-w

Awards should be standard-bearers for transparent, robust research that is inclusive, equitable and trustworthy. But that is not what they are right now.
item.dc:title: Research prizes are opaque and rife with bias — it’s time to shake them up
item.dc:creator: Malgorzata Lagisz

Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03794-w

Mutant ion pumps help brine shrimp survive highly saline waters.

item.dc:creator: Lucia Brunello

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04031-0

item.dc:creator: Jack Leeming

item.title: A light-driven enzymatic enantioselective radical acylation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06822-x

Enzyme-bound ketyl radicals derived from thiamine diphosphate are selectively generated through single-electron oxidation by a photoexcited organic dye and shown to lead to enantioselective radical acylation reactions.
item.dc:title: A light-driven enzymatic enantioselective radical acylation

item.title: Unequal climate impacts on global values of natural capital
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06769-z

Country-level changes in economic production and the value of non-market ecosystem benefits show unequal impacts on the global values of natural capital resulting from climate-change-induced shifts in terrestrial vegetation cover.
item.dc:title: Unequal climate impacts on global values of natural capital

item.title: The scientific workplace in 2023
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04030-1

India’s first Moon landing and a welcome return to Horizon Europe for UK researchers loomed large in an eventful year for working scientists around the world.
item.dc:title: The scientific workplace in 2023
item.dc:creator: Chris Woolston

item.title: The science events to watch for in 2024
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04044-9

Advanced AI tools, Moon missions and ultrafast supercomputers are among the developments set to shape research in the coming year.
item.dc:title: The science events to watch for in 2024
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Oceans can capture more carbon dioxide than previously thought
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03662-7

The strength of the biological carbon pump was estimated using direct measurements of nutrients collected over decades. The findings indicate that ocean waters can capture and store larger amounts of carbon dioxide than previously estimated. This might have implications for climate-change models.
item.dc:title: Oceans can capture more carbon dioxide than previously thought

item.title: Prebunking propaganda, and how to live well: 2023’s best of Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04026-x

Connoisseur Andrew Robinson gives ten of his favourite tomes from the year a more expansive review.
item.dc:title: Prebunking propaganda, and how to live well: 2023’s best of Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Crossing the generational divide: what established scientists and early-career researchers can learn from each other
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04069-0

Astrophysicist and Shaw prizewinner Victoria Kaspi describes how science forums can help researchers of all ages to share ideas and career concerns.
item.dc:title: Crossing the generational divide: what established scientists and early-career researchers can learn from each other
item.dc:creator: Kamal Nahas

item.title: Daily briefing: Repeated ignition signals nuclear-fusion breakthrough
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04074-3

An experimental fusion lab is sparking hope for a future power source. Plus, a bullying scandal has scuppered a storied astronomy department and Science names GLP-1 weightloss drugs as its breakthrough of the year.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Repeated ignition signals nuclear-fusion breakthrough
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Muscle immune cells protect mitochondrial organelles during exercise
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03972-w

A suppressive type of immune cell called a regulatory T cell has a key role in helping muscles to adapt to exercise — guarding muscle mitochondrial organelles against damage mediated by proinflammatory factors generated during physical activity.
item.dc:title: Muscle immune cells protect mitochondrial organelles during exercise
item.dc:creator: Gerald Coulis
S. Armando Villalta

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: How to parent AI, and climate change vs democracy: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Navigating planets, plays and prejudice — a conversation with Aomawa Shields
item.content:encoded:

The astronomer joins us to talk about her memoir Life on Other Planets.
item.dc:title: Navigating planets, plays and prejudice — a conversation with Aomawa Shields
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Daily briefing: Farm animals have complex mental lives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04068-1

Research is giving insight into the minds of cows, pigs, and other livestock. Plus, aspects of the human genome are unique to Indigenous Australians, and a first glimpse at a tyrannosaur’s last meal.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Farm animals have complex mental lives
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.dc:title: Wetlands, neutrinos and warning coloration: kicking off a year of remarkable science

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04045-8

Researchers at the National Ignition Facility are consistently creating reactions that make more energy than they consume.

item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Inhaled vaccine prevents COVID in monkeys
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04040-z

New study suggests boosters delivered to the lungs could stop infection.
item.dc:title: Inhaled vaccine prevents COVID in monkeys
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Webcast: How water researchers are rethinking the global flood crisis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03984-6

A panel of specialists discuss the latest insights on protecting people, habitats and infrastructure from the risks of flooding.
item.dc:title: Webcast: How water researchers are rethinking the global flood crisis

item.title: Water and warfare: the battle to control a precious resource
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03883-w

Climate change could intensify the role of this vital and strategic asset in armed conflict.
item.dc:title: Water and warfare: the battle to control a precious resource
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Daily briefing: Hormone released by fetuses might cause debilitating pregnancy sickness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04049-4

Sensitivity to the hormone GDF15 might be the reason that some people experience hyperemesis gravidarum. Plus, why stressed mice sleep poorly and Nature’s pick of ten people who changed science in 2023.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Hormone released by fetuses might cause debilitating pregnancy sickness
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: How to take ‘forever’ out of forever chemicals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03876-9

Stubborn compounds called PFAS in drinking water put health at risk. Technologies based on plasmas, pressure, sound or fungus could finally degrade these chemicals.
item.dc:title: How to take ‘forever’ out of forever chemicals
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: RNA biologist loses disability case against Howard Hughes Medical Institute
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04004-3

Vivian Cheung sued after her funding was not renewed, alleging discrimination, but the institute said her science no longer met its expectations.
item.dc:title: RNA biologist loses disability case against Howard Hughes Medical Institute
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt
Max Kozlov

item.title: Water: a source of life and strife
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03961-z

Water is an essential resource, but it can also cause conflict, expose people to pollution and put communities at risk in the form of flooding.
item.dc:title: Water: a source of life and strife
item.dc:creator: Herb Brody

item.title: Why hidden xenophobia is surging into the open
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03973-9

Sociologist Mathew Creighton discusses how events in Europe in the past month are fed by people’s covert prejudices.
item.dc:title: Why hidden xenophobia is surging into the open
item.dc:creator: Emma Marris

item.title: Scientists drilled through 500 metres of Greenland’s ice — here’s what they found at the bottom
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04002-5

Bedrock extracted from beneath the island’s frozen covering offers hints of the ice sheet’s past and future.
item.dc:title: Scientists drilled through 500 metres of Greenland’s ice — here’s what they found at the bottom
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Korean lunar mission provides a view into the Moon’s dark spaces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04005-2

South Korea’s first trip to the Moon has been labelled a success.
item.dc:title: Korean lunar mission provides a view into the Moon’s dark spaces
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Sizing up hydrogen’s hydrological footprint
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03884-9

The use of hydrogen as an energy carrier is essential to decarbonizing economies. Industrial policies and technology developments could trim the water consumption involved in producing the gas, minimizing its cost and environmental impact.
item.dc:title: Sizing up hydrogen’s hydrological footprint
item.dc:creator: Peter Fairley

item.title: Fresh water from thin air
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03875-w

Strategies for collecting water from the atmosphere using minimal energy could fill a crucial gap in sustaining communities that have limited access to water.
item.dc:title: Fresh water from thin air
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: The most important issue about water is not supply, but how it is used
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03899-2

The world faces a series of deep and worsening crises that demand radical changes in how we understand, manage and use fresh water.
item.dc:title: The most important issue about water is not supply, but how it is used
item.dc:creator: Peter Gleick

item.title: The human factor in water disasters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03962-y

Decisions about land use and infrastructure have left little space for water, amplifying the effects of natural disasters and climate change.
item.dc:title: The human factor in water disasters
item.dc:creator: Erica Gies

item.title: DeepMind AI outdoes human mathematicians on unsolved problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04043-w

Large language model improves on efforts to solve combinatorics problems inspired by the card game Set.
item.dc:title: DeepMind AI outdoes human mathematicians on unsolved problem
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Pay disputes linger for academics one year after historic US research strike
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03873-y

Some 2,000 graduate student workers say they aren’t receiving wages agreed upon by the University of California, but a resolution is near.
item.dc:title: Pay disputes linger for academics one year after historic US research strike
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo
